title.narrative: Supporting Colombian productivity and harmonious economic and social development, by means of strengthening vocational education in the port, transport and logistics sectors

participating-org.narrative: Servicio Nacional de Aprendizaje de Colombia (SENA)

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: DO NOT USE Labour market and entrepreneurship

description.narrative:
**(if applicable)** Describe the progress that is made in strengthening the capacity of the requesting organisation to deliver the products and services which are demanded by the labour market and society in general? Has competitiveness / efficiency been improved?
In case the requesting organisation is an education institution, what are the prospects of graduates to find employment or to become self-employed? Has the training had an impact on sectoral development?

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: DO NOT USE Labour market and entrepreneurship

description.narrative:
**(if applicable)** Describe the progress that is made in strengthening the capacity of the requesting organisation to deliver the products and services which are demanded by the labour market and society in general? Has competitiveness / efficiency been improved?
In case the requesting organisation is an education institution, what are the prospects of graduates to find employment or to become self-employed? Has the training had an impact on sectoral development?

actual.value:
In the first instance, our participants were mainly instructors. This means that now the instructors are trained to share that knowledge to SENA's TVET students.
After this, through SENA's mechanisms for the promotion and generation of employment (such as the transnational employment exchange), the skills required for the labor market, specifically in the port, maritime and transportation sectors, will begin to be reflected.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
The training contributed especially to the strengthening of human capital in the Colombian port, maritime and transportation sector, approaching it from an educational perspective.
For Colombia, this transfer of knowledge by STC International has a direct impact on the annual training plans of SENA, which is an organization that seeks to expand its educational and educational capacity in the country. for this reason, it is important to emphasize the willingness of the participants to be open to new knowledge and methodologies that contribute directly and indirectly to the growth of Colombia as a country.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
- Training hours actually executed
Taking into account the whole activities, we executed, thogether with CINOP, about 50-60 training/workshop hours.
- Training activities actually executedActivity 1. Execution of a Train-the-Trainer program on operational and technical level for SENA Instructors in Port Equipment (forklift)
2. Execution of a training program on management level for SENA lecturers in "Logistics and Port Management, Development and Regionalization".
3. Execution of a didactical Train-the-Trainer program (IMO 6.09)
4. Transversal activity, socialization workshops in the identified regions with the participants of the activities, local employment and placement agencies and the sector stakeholders.
- Training certificates granted.
More than 120 certificates granted and 2 general attendance certificates for socialization workshops
- Training penetration rate
80%
- Adjusted training materials to the local circumstances
Examination/Examination models reviwed during the IMO 6.09
- Stakeholders input and satisfaction
Sectorial table of SENA (Ministy of Transport, Private Universities and private stakeholders) participated during some activities.

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: 15 scholarships have been granted, specifically to instructors from regions of Colombia considered highly vulnerable such as (Urabá, Tumaco, Buenaventura, Turbo).

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: A total of 41 scholarships have been granted to women from different

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: All of the participants have applied the acquires knowledge through the activities/assignments during each one of the courses.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: All participants from SENA have successfully completed course/training in: - Port Development & Regionalization - Socialization Workshop STC-CINOP - IMO 6.09 and 'Train the Trainer' in port operations (Forklift)

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: Around 40% of the participants have acquired more responsibilities in their daily tasks and/or having promoted to higher strategic positions.

title.narrative: B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: For each one of the minority/vulnerable participants, one stimulating measures were taken during the preparation, supervision and after care period.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: Including SENA, Sector Tables and different terminal operators and ports in Colombia

title.narrative: B.O.3. Number of organisations with institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: SENA and the Colombian organisations to which the trained instructors have disseminate their knowledge.

title.narrative: B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: SENA. We do not know the situation of the organisations to which SENA instructors have disseminate their knowledge. | 23-02-2022: SENA. We do not know the situation of the organisations to which SENA instructors have disseminate their knowledge.

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: TMT Participant's satisfactions can be founded in the 'Evaluation of the Course' formats attached

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: Taking into account our evaluations of each one of the courses/trainings, we can confirm that all the participants have reported an acquirement either new knowledge or skills in the maritime, port and logistics matters.

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 23-02-2022: Webinar 'The role of women in the port sector' with a participation of about 80 women (trainers/trainees) | 23-02-2022: For each one of the female participants, one stimulating measures were taken during the preparation, supervision and after care period.

title.narrative: B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
All participants have shown better personal, academic and professional attitudes after the courses/trainings.
Due to this, about 40% of the participants have been promoted to higher positions and/or acquired more responsibilities.

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: Taking into account that 41 of the whole participants are women, we can conclude that this has contribute to gender equality and gender awareness. Specially, during the dissemination seminars the role of the woman has specially been considered and discussed.
